Old: >>52507707

Welcome to the Raidcat / 6 Star Tera Raid Meta Thread

>lol I can solo 5 star raids I don't need your ugly cat
6 stars are infinitely harder than 5 and extremely annoying. You can do them the normal way and risk wasting your time, or accept the raidcat as your raid savior.

>What's the meta?
4 Perrserkers. Their Hidden Ability stacks multiplicatively and, if you follow the flowchart, you can one-shot most raids.

>What's the raidcat like?
Perrserker @ Lum Berry
Level 100
Ability: Steely Spirit (Hidden Ability)
EVs: 252 Atk / 252 Speed (Host) or HP (Joiner)
Adamant Nature
- Iron Head
- Screech
- Swords Dance
- Taunt (Host) / Helping Hand (Joiner)

>Host? Joiner? Flowchart?
There's a small difference in strategy whether you are hosting or joining a raid and a specific flowchart. See OP pic.

>Does this work every time?
No, but it's one of the only consistent strategies that you can follow. It's not great against Pokemon that have strong and/or STAB Fire/Fighting/Ground moves, and if their Tera resists Steel it can also take a few more turn (but still doable).

>So what's the hype?
Catraids are simple to organize, have plenty of flowcharts, and finish the job very quickly. It's about efficiency.

>I have a question about raids...
Check OP pic.

>How to get cat with HA?
Language Teacher sidequest, then use an Ability Patch to change its ability. Patch is an 11% drop from 6 Star Raids.

>I tried breeding but I'm getting Kantonian Meowth
Make the G-Meowth hold an Everstone

>wtf I did that but none of them have Steely Spirit
G-Meowth's HA is Unnerve, it becomes Steely Spirit upon evolution.

For other viable meta strategies and mons, Ctrl+F OTHERMONS

For specific strategies, Ctrl+F HARDRAIDS

Use this thread to trade for raidcats, to organize (raidcat) raids, or just to discuss and ask questions about raids in general.

>>52516010
>is not comparable to our world, it should never have been pushed in that direction
But it was that way from the very first games. Part of its appeal was as a refreshing take on the RPG formula, taking it out of the typical, vaguely medieval fantasy world and into a modern world like our own. People in RGBY play Mario on SNES, watch TV and listen to the radio, go to pachinko parlors and nostalgically remember the real-life Moon landing.
In GSC they've all got mobile phones comparable to Japanese garake and travel by Shinkansen. The Japanese version of Crystal even features connectivity with real-life garake.
This has always been part of the series, you're just noticing it more due to your familiarity with contemporary technology.

Aggron should have been Steel/Ground. Comparing the defensive typings of Steel/Rock and Steel/Ground. It just isn't fair.

Even though Steel/Rock has a quad resistance to Normal and Flying, those are primarily physical attackers, so just resisting them is fine enough. And while you would get a weakness to fire as a result of being Ground. A Steel/Rock has two quad weaknesses to both Fighting and Ground, which are the two best attacking types in the games.

A quad weakness is already really hard to work with, but two is suicidal. Which is why Mega Aggron was so good just becoming pure steel since Aggron was so bad defensively.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>52514627
Each ingredient contributes to at least one type of meal power. Might also detract from other meal powers.
Each ingredient also contributes one or more commonly several pokemon types.
And then ingredients also contribute and detract towards a bunch of taste categories.

The meal power with the highest score becomes
Meal power #1
The meal power with the second highest score becomes
Meal power #2
And the power with the third highest score becomes
Meal power #3

The type with the highest score gets assigned to power #1. The type with the second highest score gets assigned to power #2. And the type with the third highest score gets assigned to power #3.
And if you want higher level meal powers you need to ramp up its score even higher.

The tastes scores determine whether or not the sandwich actually ends up edible or not, but I've got no clue how that part actually works.

VGC is broken up into "series" to prolong the game's lifespan.
Pre-dexit it was usually 3 separate rulesets, each lasting a year - Regional Dex, National Dex and National Dex + Restricted Legendaries.

Since SwSh they obviously have fewer Pokemon to play with so they make small rules like this, which would have been single-weekend cups in the XY-SM era.
The next series could allow the paradoxes, or it could be the same ruleset with the top 10 mons of this one banned (this was at least one of the series in SwSh).

>Literally why does it matter? If the weak current species couldn't survive then they should have just been wiped out by the superior paradoxmons. It's not like anything would change, just weaker Pokemon would get replaced by strong ones.
That isn't how invasive species work you fucking retard. When you introduce something into an environment that's too apex for the local food chain, here's what happens:
>Invasive species outcompetes peers
>Peers die
>Prey and resources the invasive species is consuming are not equipped to handle this new apex species
>Prey becomes extinct too, resources disappear
>Apex species no longer has any prey or resources to consume either
>Apex species also goes extinct
This isn't a "survival of the fittest" thing. But I wouldn't expect some pseudo-intellectal zoomer who thinks he understands how ecosystems work because he took high school biology to understand that.
